choices.text: Tip of nose to ear to xiphisternum
Tip of nose to angle of ear to umbilicus
Mouth to ear to umbilicus
Mouth to ear to midway between xiphisternum and umbilicus

questions.text: As an intern in emergency ward, which of the following method would you consider as correct regarding nasogastric tube length estimation? (AIIMS NOV 2018)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Tip of nose to ear to xiphisternum (i.e., N-E-X)

 

Approximate length of nasogastric tube is 120 -125cm     

 

How to confirm correct position of NG tube:

 

  • Auscultation in the epigastric area while injecting a bolus of air
  • x-ray chest
  • Colorimetric capnography

 

 

XIPHISTERNUM

 

Place the tip of the nasogastric tube at the tip of the nose, then measure from the nose to the ear lobe & down to the tip of the Xiphisternum

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Tip of nose to angle of ear to umbilicus: This measurement is too long as it typically extends beyond the stomach, potentially reaching into the intestines.

 

Option C. Mouth to ear to umbilicus: This measurement is also incorrect and typically used for other medical estimations, not for NG tube placement.

 

Option D. Mouth to ear to midway between xiphisternum and umbilicus: Similar to option B, this measurement is excessively long for proper NG tube placement.

 

Educational Objective:

 

When inserting a nasogastric tube, the correct measurement to estimate the necessary tube length is from the tip of the nose to the earlobe to the xiphisternum, ensuring the tube reaches the stomach properly for effective therapeutic or diagnostic use.

questions.text: A young patient presents to the clinic with erythematous lesions over the exposed areas of the skin like hands, arms, chest, etc. She also complains of arthralgia and breathlessness. Which among the following antibodies will be useful in diagnosing this condition? (INICET NOV 2022)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Anti-dsDNA antibodies

 

The patient exhibits symptoms including erythematous lesions on sun-exposed areas of the skin, arthralgia, and breathlessness, which are characteristic of Systemic Lupus Erythematosus (SLE). The rash described is typical of an SLE rash and not dermatomyositis, which presents with rashes over the knuckles known as Gottron's papules.

 

For diagnosing SLE, anti-dsDNA antibodies are very useful due to their high specificity. Although their sensitivity is relatively low (30-50%), the specificity is very high (>90-95%), making them reliable markers for confirming the diagnosis of SLE. Anti-dsDNA antibodies are also associated with disease activity in SLE.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Antihistone antibodies: These are primarily associated with drug-induced lupus erythematosus, not classic SLE.

 

Option C. Anticentromere antibodies: These are typically seen in limited forms of scleroderma, particularly CREST syndrome, and are not associated with SLE.

 

Option D. Antinuclear antibodies (ANA): While ANA is a good initial screening test for SLE due to its high sensitivity, it lacks specificity. ANA can be positive in a variety of autoimmune conditions, thus it is not as specific as anti-dsDNA antibodies for diagnosing SLE.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Anti-dsDNA antibodies are highly specific for diagnosing Systemic Lupus Erythematosus (SLE), despite their moderate sensitivity.

choices.text: Chronic respiratory acidosis, acute metabolic alkalosis
Acute respiratory acidosis, acute respiratory alkalosis
Acute Metabolic alkalosis, acute respiratory acidosis
Acute respiratory acidosis, acute metabolic alkalosis

questions.text: Identify the areas marked F, C in the following diagram: (INICET NOV 2020)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Acute respiratory acidosis, acute respiratory alkalosis

 

  • Area F: Positioned in the lower left part of the diagram, which corresponds to higher PCO2 and a pH less than 7.35. This area represents Acute Respiratory Acidosis due to an increase in CO2, causing a drop in blood pH.
  • Area C: Positioned in the upper right part of the diagram, which corresponds to lower PCO2 and a pH greater than 7.45. This area represents Acute Respiratory Alkalosis caused by a decrease in CO2, increasing blood pH.

 

 

 

Educational Objective:

 

Understanding the relationship between pH, bicarbonate (HCO3-), and CO2 is crucial for interpreting arterial blood gases. Area F indicates acute respiratory acidosis due to increased CO2, and area C indicates acute respiratory alkalosis due to decreased CO2.

questions.text: Which among the following is WRONG regarding Claude's syndrome? (Twisted PYQ)
questions.solution:
Ans. C. Contralateral hemiballismus

 

Explanation:


Claude's syndrome is a midbrain syndrome caused by lesions involving the red nucleus and oculomotor nerve. The key features include:

  • Ipsilateral oculomotor nerve palsy: Damage to cranial nerve III causes ptosis, pupillary dilation, and impaired eye movement.
  • Contralateral ataxia: Lesion of the red nucleus or dentato-rubro-thalamic tract leads to coordination deficits on the opposite side of the body.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A: Contralateral ataxia: Incorrect because contralateral ataxia is a hallmark feature of Claude's syndrome due to red nucleus involvement.

 

Option B: Ipsilateral oculomotor nerve palsy: Incorrect because Claude's syndrome commonly affects cranial nerve III, causing oculomotor palsy on the same side as the lesion.

 

Option D: Contralateral hemiplegia: Incorrect because hemiplegia is associated with Weber’s syndrome, not Claude's syndrome.

 

Educational Objective:


Claude's syndrome is characterized by ipsilateral oculomotor nerve palsy and contralateral ataxia due to lesions in the midbrain affecting the red nucleus and associated tracts. Contralateral hemiballismus is not a feature of Claude's syndrome and is more commonly linked to subthalamic nucleus damage.

questions.text: A young patient presents in a multi-specialty hospital with sudden onset chest pain since 1 hour with ECG showing ST elevation in leads II, III, and aVF. What is the best treatment? (FMGE JANUARY 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Primary Angioplasty

 

Explanation:

 

The patient presents with symptoms and ECG findings indicative of an acute inferior ST-elevation myocardial infarction (STEMI). The presence of ST elevation in leads II, III, and aVF confirms the diagnosis. Primary percutaneous coronary intervention (PCI), also known as primary angioplasty, is the best treatment for STEMI if it can be performed promptly. PCI is preferred because it directly opens the blocked coronary artery, restoring blood flow more quickly and effectively than thrombolytic therapy.

 

Note - If Primary PCI not possible or delayed due to some reasons then thrombolytic therapy (dual antiplatelet therapy) is used.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Alteplase: This is a thrombolytic agent used to dissolve clots but is considered when PCI is not available or will be delayed.

 

Option B. Streptokinase: Another thrombolytic agent, similar to alteplase, used when PCI is not an option.

 

Option D. Dual Antiplatelet therapy: This is an essential part of the initial management of STEMI, involving a combination of aspirin and a P2Y12 receptor inhibitor (like clopidogrel, ticagrelor, or prasugrel). However, it is not the definitive treatment compared to PCI.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Primary angioplasty (PCI) is the best treatment for patients presenting with STEMI, especially when it can be performed within the recommended time frame, as it effectively restores blood flow to the affected myocardium. ​

questions.text: Components of the MELD (2016) score are all except? (INICET NOV 2020)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Albumin

 

The Model for End-Stage Liver Disease (MELD) score is used to prioritize patients for liver transplantation and assesses the severity of chronic liver disease. The MELD score includes three laboratory values:

 

“CBI mnemonic = Creatinine, Bilirubin, INR are the parameters is MELD score.

 

Currently Sodium levels to the score and MELD-Na score used for prognostication. Hyponatremia associated with adverse outcomes.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Bilirubin: Reflects the liver's ability to excrete bilirubin.

 

Option C. INR (International Normalized Ratio) for prothrombin time: Indicates the liver's ability to synthesize clotting factors.

 

Option D. Creatinine: Assesses renal function, which can be compromised in liver failure. Additionally, sodium was added to the MELD score to improve its prognostic accuracy, resulting in the MELD-Na score.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Albumin is not a component of the MELD score. The key components are bilirubin, creatinine, and INR, with sodium also included in the updated MELD-Na scoring system to better predict outcomes in patients with end-stage liver disease.

 

Reference: Harrison 21/Cirrhosis/Chap 344

questions.text: A 37-year-old woman presents with headaches for 6 months. She has been taking analgesics regularly. The headache recently increased in severity for 3 days but was reduced on stopping the analgesic. What is the likely diagnosis? (NEET PG 2021)
questions.solution:
Ans. A. Medication overuse headache

 

Medication overuse headache (MOH) occurs in individuals who frequently use headache medications. The patient in this case has been experiencing headaches for six months and has been regularly using analgesics. The key indicator of MOH is the worsening of headaches with continued use of medication and improvement upon stopping the medication. This aligns with the patient's experience of increased headache severity for three days, which reduced once the analgesics were stopped.

 

MOH develops as a result of the brain becoming sensitized to the medication, leading to a rebound effect. This is a well-recognized phenomenon where the headache itself is caused by the frequent use of headache relief medication, leading to a cycle of medication use and headache.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Tension headache: Tension headaches are typically relieved by analgesics, not worsened. These headaches are often characterized by a feeling of a tight band around the head and can be managed effectively with over-the-counter pain relief medications. 

 

  • Acute Treatment: Nonsteroidal anti-inflammatory drugs (NSAIDs) or paracetamol are used to relieve pain.
  • Chronic Treatment: Tricyclic antidepressants, such as amitriptyline, are employed to manage chronic symptoms and reduce the recurrence of headaches.

 

Option C. Chronic migraine: Chronic migraines are managed with both acute treatments for individual attacks and preventive treatments to reduce the frequency and severity of the headaches. While chronic migraines can be debilitating, they generally improve with proper prophylaxis and do not worsen with the use of analgesics.

 

  • Treatment options include propranolol, topiramate, valproate, and monoclonal antibodies against CGRP (calcitonin gene-related peptide), such as erenumab. These are used to reduce the frequency and severity of migraine attacks.

 

Option D. Cluster headache: Cluster headaches are severe, unilateral headaches that are treated with high-flow oxygen and subcutaneous sumatriptan during acute attacks. Preventive treatments include medications like verapamil. Analgesics are not typically the first-line treatment for cluster headaches and their use does not generally lead to worsening of the condition.

 

  • Acute Treatment: High-flow 100% oxygen inhalation or subcutaneous sumatriptan injections are recommended to alleviate the intense pain of acute cluster headache attacks.
  • Chronic Treatment: Verapamil is used for long-term management to prevent the frequency and intensity of cluster headache episodes.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Medication overuse headache is characterized by the worsening of headaches due to frequent use of headache medications, and improvement upon cessation of the medication. This phenomenon highlights the importance of managing headache disorders with appropriate treatments and avoiding overuse of analgesics.

questions.text: A patient presented with violent, flinging movements. Where is the lesion causing the hemiballismus seen? (INICET NOV 2022)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Subthalamic nucleus

 

Hemiballismus is characterized by involuntary, violent, flinging movements, typically on one side of the body. This condition is most commonly associated with a lesion in the subthalamic nucleus. The subthalamic nucleus plays a crucial role in regulating movements, and damage to this area can lead to the excessive, uncontrolled movements seen in hemiballismus. This differentiates it from lesions in other parts of the basal ganglia, which are associated with different movement disorders.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Putamen: Lesions in the putamen are more commonly associated with chorea, which involves rapid, involuntary, and irregular movements, rather than the violent flinging movements of hemiballismus.

 

Option C. Caudate nucleus: Similar to the putamen, lesions in the caudate nucleus typically result in chorea. The caudate nucleus is part of the striatum, and its dysfunction does not usually present with the violent movements characteristic of hemiballismus.

 

Option D. Globus pallidus: Lesions in the globus pallidus often result in athetosis, which involves slow, writhing movements. This is different from the abrupt and forceful movements seen in hemiballismus.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Hemiballismus, characterized by violent, flinging movements, is most commonly caused by a lesion in the subthalamic nucleus.

questions.text: What levels of prolactin are definitely suggestive of prolactinoma? (NEET PG 2018)
questions.solution:
Ans. D. > 200 ug/L

 

Prolactin levels greater than 200 ug/L are definitely suggestive of a prolactinoma. This level typically indicates the presence of a prolactin-secreting pituitary adenoma. The significant elevation in prolactin can cause clinical symptoms such as galactorrhea and amenorrhea in women, or hypogonadism in men. The diagnosis is further supported by imaging studies such as MRI, which can visualize the adenoma.

 

Additional Information

 

 

Educational Objective:

questions.text: A 50-year-old male patient presents with headache and seizures. On examination his BP is 220/110 mm Hg. What is the most appropriate treatment? (FMGE JULY 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) IV Labetalol

 

In this case, the patient is experiencing a neurological hypertensive emergency, as indicated by his headache and seizures alongside a high blood pressure reading of 220/110 mm Hg. This condition could stem from several serious issues, including ischemic stroke, intracranial hemorrhage, or hypertensive encephalopathy.

 

The primary objective in managing a neurological hypertensive emergency is to safely reduce the blood pressure. For such emergencies, the first-line treatments typically include IV Nicardipine or IV Labetalol. Given that IV nicardipine is often not available in many Indian hospitals, IV labetalol becomes the preferred option, making it the Ans. in this scenario.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. IV Nitroglycerin: Nitrates, such as nitroglycerin, are generally avoided in neurological emergencies because they cause vasodilation, which can increase cerebral blood flow. This increase in blood flow can elevate intracranial pressure, potentially worsening the patient's condition.

 

Option C. Oral Nifedipine: Oral medications are not suitable for emergency situations due to their delayed onset of action. Immediate reduction of blood pressure is crucial in this case, making oral nifedipine inappropriate.

 

Option D. IV Hydralazine: Although IV hydralazine is an arterial vasodilator, it is not recommended for neurological hypertensive emergencies. Similar to nitrates, it can lead to an increase in intracranial pressure and potentially exacerbate the patient's symptoms.

 

Educational Objective:

 

In neurological hypertensive emergencies, the first-line treatment options for reducing blood pressure are IV nicardipine or IV labetalol, with IV labetalol being preferred if IV nicardipine is unavailable.

questions.text: Which of the following is earliest to rise in myocardial infarction? (FMGE JULY 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Ischemia modified albumin

 

Explanation:

 

In the event of a myocardial infarction, certain biomarkers are released into the bloodstream as a result of cardiac muscle injury.

 

Among the three early markers of myocardial injury, three are particularly significant: myoglobin, heart-type fatty acid binding protein (HFABP), and ischemia modified albumin (IMA). Of these three, ischemia modified albumin is the earliest to rise and also the earliest to fall in response to myocardial ischemia. This rapid change makes it a valuable early diagnostic marker for detecting myocardial infarction.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Troponin: Troponins are highly specific markers for myocardial injury and are considered the gold standard for diagnosing myocardial infarction. However, they do not rise as early as ischemia modified albumin. Typically, troponin levels start to rise 4-6 hours after the onset of myocardial infarction.

 

Option C. LDH (Lactate Dehydrogenase): LDH is an enzyme found in almost all body tissues and is not specific to cardiac tissue. It is a later marker of myocardial infarction, usually rising within 24-48 hours after the onset of symptoms.

 

Option D. CK MB (Creatine Kinase-MB): CK-MB is a specific isoenzyme found in heart muscle and is used as a marker for myocardial infarction. However, it does not rise as early as ischemia modified albumin. CK-MB levels typically start to increase 3-6 hours after myocardial infarction.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Ischemia modified albumin is the earliest biomarker to rise in the event of a myocardial infarction, making it a crucial early indicator for diagnosis.

choices.text: Loud S1 is a common finding
Echo will show diastolic RA/RV collapse

questions.text: A 45-year-old female with a history of chest pain and upper respiratory tract infection, seven days ago, presents with shortness of breath. She has BP of 100/60 mm Hg and a pulse rate of 110/min. Chest x-ray reviews an enlarged heart, which appears like a water bottle. Which of the following is incorrect? (INICET MAY 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Loud S1 is a common finding

 

The patient is likely suffering from pericardial effusion, possibly progressing to cardiac tamponade, secondary to a recent viral infection. This is suggested by the history of an upper respiratory tract infection, the physical findings, and the characteristic "water bottle" appearance of the heart on the chest x-ray.

 

The incorrect statement is Loud S1 is a common finding. In fact, one of the hallmarks of cardiac tamponade is muffled or distant heart sounds due to the insulating effect of the pericardial fluid, as described in Beck's triad, which includes hypotension, jugular venous distension, and muffled heart sounds.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Pulsus Paradoxus is usually seen: This is true. Pulsus paradoxus is a significant drop in blood pressure during inspiration, common in cardiac tamponade.

 

Option B. Pericardiocentesis may be required: This is true. Pericardiocentesis is often necessary to remove the excess fluid and relieve pressure on the heart, especially if the patient is hemodynamically unstable.

 

Option D. Echo will show diastolic RA/RV collapse: This is true. In cardiac tamponade, the pressure from the pericardial fluid prevents the right atrium and right ventricle from expanding during diastole, leading to their collapse. Echocardiography will reveal this diastolic collapse, confirming cardiac tamponade.

 

Educational Objective:

 

In cardiac tamponade, muffled heart sounds are a key finding, not a loud S1.

questions.text: A woman with Grave's disease was taking antithyroid medication throughout her pregnancy. The baby was born with aplasia cutis congenita. Which drug could have caused this condition? (INICET NOV 2020)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Carbimazole

 

Carbimazole is a medication used to treat hyperthyroidism and is known to cause teratogenic effects if used during pregnancy. It can lead to a rare congenital condition called aplasia cutis congenita, where the baby is born with localized areas of missing skin. The use of carbimazole, especially during the first trimester of pregnancy, is linked with this embryopathy, which highlights the importance of careful medication selection in pregnant women with thyroid disorders.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Methylthiouracil: Although it is an antithyroid drug, it is less commonly used and not specifically associated with aplasia cutis congenita.

 

Option C. Levothyroxine: This is a thyroid hormone replacement and is used to treat hypothyroidism, not associated with congenital defects.

 

Option D. Hydrouracil: This option appears to be a distractor as no such common drug name exists that is relevant in this context.

 

Educational Objective:

 

MMZ, Carbimazole associated with embryonopathy in first trimester

 

Graves in Pregnancy:

 

<16 weeks: PTU (MM teratogenic)

 

>16 weeks: MMI (PTU hepatotoxicity)

 

Lactation: MMI (RAIA avoided 4-6 weeks after cessation of breastfeeding as RAI is concentrated in breast tissue)

 

Reference - Harrison 21/Hyperthyroidism/Graves/Chap 384

choices.text: Hyperthyroidism due to disease in the pituitary
Hypothyroidism due to disease in the pituitary
Hypothyroidism due to disease in the hypothalamus
Hyperthyroidism due to disease in the hypothalamus

questions.text: A patient came to the hospital with complaints of lethargy, increased sleep, and weight gain. Investigations revealed low plasma TSH concentration. However, on the administration of TRH, the TSH levels increased. Which of the following conditions is likely in this patient? (NEET PG 2020)
questions.solution:
Ans. C. Hypothyroidism due to disease in the hypothalamus

 

Clinical history is suggestive of hypothyroidism. Presence of low TSH with suspected hypothyroidism indicates loss of Log relationship of TSH & fT4 indicating a central cause. Administration of TRH improving TSH level indicates TRH deficiency which is mainly produced from the hypothalamus.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A.  Hyperthyroidism due to pituitary:  Cause like TSHoma is very rare. Also, symptoms of thyrotoxicosis are not present in the patient.

 

Option B. In pituitary disease: TSH will not improve with TRH administration as the gland is defective and cannot produce TSH.

 

Option D. Thyrotoxicosis symptoms are not present in this patient.

 

Educational Objective:

 

When evaluating a patient with hypothyroid symptoms and low TSH that responds to TRH administration, consider hypothalamic dysfunction as a probable cause. This is indicative of secondary hypothyroidism due to a lack of TRH production, affecting the pituitary’s secretion of TSH in the absence of exogenous stimulation.

 

Reference - Harrison/Hypothyroidism/Chap 383

questions.text: A patient has muffled heart sounds with low BP and elevated JVP. What is the likely JVP finding? (FMGE JANUARY 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Absent y descent

 

The clinical presentation of muffled heart sounds, low blood pressure, and elevated jugular venous pressure (JVP) suggests cardiac tamponade. In cardiac tamponade, the JVP is elevated, and the typical waveform finding is a prominent x descent with a blunted or diminished y descent. This pattern is due to the restricted filling of the right atrium and ventricle during diastole because of the pressure exerted by the pericardial fluid.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Absent a wave: This is seen in patients with atrial fibrillation, where there is no organized atrial contraction.

 

Option C. Prominent y descent: This is seen in patients with constrictive pericarditis, where there is a rapid early diastolic filling, known as Friedrich's sign.

 

Option D. Absent x descent: This is a feature of tricuspid regurgitation, where the backward flow of blood during systole reduces the x descent.

 

Educational Objective:

 

In cardiac tamponade, the JVP waveform shows a prominent x descent with an absent or blunted y descent. This is due to the restricted filling of the right heart chambers caused by the pericardial fluid, leading to characteristic clinical signs such as muffled heart sounds, hypotension, and elevated JVP

choices.text: Repeat Inj. adenosine 6 mg
Inj. amiodarone 300 mg

questions.text: The ECG of a patient who presented to the ER is as given below. The patient was already given a carotid massage and IV Adenosine but the BP is currently 60/30 mm Hg. What is the next best step of management? (AIIMS NOV 2019)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Synchronized Cardioversion

 

Any hemodynamically unstable rhythm, requires synchronized cardioversion (Shock delivered in sync with R wave to prevent R-on T phenomenon).

 

Synchronized Cardioversion is the correct choice for a hemodynamically unstable patient, as it is intended to restore normal heart rhythm without causing further cardiac risks. Synchronization ensures that the shock is delivered at a safe point in the QRS complex to prevent the induction of ventricular fibrillation.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Maximum of 30mg of adenosine can be tried if patient is Hemodynamically Stable

 

Option C. Amiodarone is used in the treatment of chronic arrhythmias and rarely for acute treatment of SVT

 

Option D. DC cardioversion technically refers to the same treatment as synchronized cardioversion in the context of unstable rhythms but the lack of specification about synchronization could imply a risk if not properly timed.

 

Synchronised cardioversion avoid possibility of R on T phenomenon.

 

 

 

Educational Objective:

 

In cases of hemodynamically unstable tachyarrhythmias where initial pharmacological interventions fail, synchronized cardioversion should be promptly employed to stabilize the patient. This technique is crucial for preventing progression to more severe complications such as cardiac arrest.

questions.text: Samter’s triad refers to the association of Aspirin-sensitive asthma and: (NEET PG 2017)
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Nasal polyp

 

Explanation:

 

Samter's triad (also called AERD - Aspirin Exacerbated Respiratory Disease) consists of nasal polyps, bronchial asthma, and aspirin hypersensitivity. This classic triad represents a specific phenotype of asthma that often presents with severe symptoms and can be challenging to manage due to the multiple body systems involved and the potential for severe reactions to NSAIDs.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Obesity: While obesity can be associated with asthma and may contribute to its severity, it is not a component of Samter's triad. Obesity is a risk factor for OSA and can worsen asthma control, but it's not part of this specific syndrome.

 

Option B. Urticaria: Urticaria (hives) is not part of Samter's triad. While aspirin sensitivity can sometimes cause urticaria in some patients, it's not a defining feature of Samter's triad which specifically involves the respiratory tract.

 

Option D. Rhinosinusitis: While patients with Samter's triad frequently have chronic rhinosinusitis, the specific defining feature mentioned in the triad is nasal polyps, not rhinosinusitis itself. Nasal polyps represent a more specific pathological finding.

 

Educational Objective: 

 

Samter's triad is the specific association of three clinical entities: nasal polyps, bronchial asthma, and aspirin hypersensitivity, representing a distinct clinical syndrome requiring specific management considerations.

questions.text: A 40-year-old patient presents with chest pain and an ECG was taken. What will be the likely diagnosis? (FMGE JULY 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Anterior MI

 

The ECG shows ST elevations primarily in leads V1, V2, V3, and V4. These elevations are also seen to some extent in V5 and aVL, with reciprocal ST depressions in leads II, III, and aVF. These findings are characteristic of an anterior myocardial infarction (MI).

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Inferior MI: This would present with ST elevations in leads II, III, and aVF. These changes are not observed in the provided ECG.

 

Option C. Lateral MI: This type of MI would show ST elevations primarily in leads I, aVL, and possibly V5 and V6, but not in leads V1 to V4.

 

Option D. Posterior MI: The diagnosis of a posterior MI is typically confirmed by obtaining posterior leads (V7, V8, and V9) to demonstrate ST elevations. Alternatively, it can be inferred from characteristic ST depressions in leads V1 and V2, often with a tall R wave and upright T wave, which are not seen in this case.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Anterior MI is characterized by ST elevations in leads V1 to V4, with possible involvement of V5 and AVL, and reciprocal ST depressions in leads II, III, and aVF.

questions.text: Following is a graphic representation of a patient admitted in medicine ward with fever. What could be the possible diagnosis? (AIIMS MAY 2020)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Leptospirosis

 

Image shows typical biphasic illness with initial leptospiremic phase followed by immune phase.

 

Other illness that shows biphasic pattern include measles, Tick borne encephalitis virus, rarely Zika virus.

 

Modified Faine Criteria is used for diagnosis.

 

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Monophasic illness with predominant CNS and multisystem involvement.

 

Option C. Undulant fever presenting with PUO, muscle pain, thoracic backpain

 

Option D. Enteric fever causes step ladder pattern of fever.

 

 

Educational Objective:
 

Leptospirosis should be considered in patients presenting with a biphasic fever pattern, especially when supported by epidemiologic data pointing to possible exposure to contaminated water or animals. Early diagnosis and treatment are crucial to prevent complications such as Weil's disease, which can lead to severe renal and hepatic issues.

 

Reference - Harrison 21/Leptospirosis/Chap 184

choices.text: Stop the treatment and follow up
Continue treatment for another 2 years
Gradually taper the drug and stop treatment
Continue lifelong treatment with antiepileptics

questions.text: A 16-year-old who is taking antiepileptics, has had a seizure-free period of 6 months. She has no family history of epilepsy. Her EEG is now normal and she has a normal neurological exam and intelligence. What would be your advice? (AIIMS MAY 2019)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Continue treatment for another 2 years

 

In cases of epilepsy, particularly in children and adolescents, the continuation of antiepileptic drug (AED) therapy after a period of being seizure-free is typically recommended for about 2 years. This recommendation is based on the need to stabilize neurological function and minimize the risk of recurrence. The decision to discontinue AEDs should consider factors such as the duration of being seizure-free, EEG findings, the type of epilepsy, and the individual’s neurological examination.

 

Rationale for Continuing Treatment:

 

  • Continuing AED treatment for at least 2 years after achieving seizure control helps ensure the stability of the condition and reduces the likelihood of seizure recurrence, especially during the critical developmental years of adolescence.
  • Recurrences are most common in the first 3 months after discontinuing AEDs, making a cautious approach necessary.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Stop the treatment and follow up: This would be risky given the short period of seizure freedom (only 6 months). Stopping treatment prematurely may lead to recurrence.

 

Option C. Gradually taper the drug and stop treatment: This is typically considered after a longer period of seizure freedom, usually a minimum of 2 years, not just 6 months.

 

Option D. Continue lifelong treatment with antiepileptics: This is generally reserved for cases of refractory epilepsy where seizures cannot be controlled with multiple medications, which does not seem to be the case here based on the information provided.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Anti-epileptics once initiated must be continued for a minimum period of 2 years. Decision to stop AED is considered if, seizure free > 2 years with normal MRI, EEG, seizure type.

 

Recurrences occur in the first 3 months of discontinuing AED.

 

Reference - Harrison principles of internal Medicine 21st edition Pg. 12076

questions.text: A patient with retro-positive status was started on 2nd line highly active antiretroviral therapy (HAART). Which of the following can be used to monitor treatment efficacy? (Neet pg 2022)
questions.solution:
Ans. B. Viral load

 

Viral load measurement is the primary method used to monitor the efficacy of antiretroviral therapy (ART) in patients with HIV. According to WHO and NACO guidelines, the monitoring of viral load is crucial for assessing the effectiveness of the treatment. Initially, viral load is monitored every six months until the regimen is stabilized. After that, it is monitored annually.

 

The goal of ART is to achieve an undetectable viral load, defined as less than 50 copies per mL. If the viral load is less than 50 copies, it indicates effective suppression of the virus, and the patient can continue with the same ART regimen with yearly monitoring.

 

If the viral load exceeds 1000 copies, it suggests treatment failure, necessitating a change in the ART regimen.

 

For viral loads between 50 and 1000 copies, the issue is often due to poor adherence to therapy, and it is recommended to ensure adherence and frequently monitor viral load every three months until suppression is achieved.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. CD4+ T cell count: Previously, CD4+ T cell count was commonly used to monitor HIV treatment. However, current guidelines prioritize viral load over CD4 count for monitoring treatment efficacy. While CD4 count is still important for assessing the immune system's health, it is not the primary marker for treatment efficacy.

 

Option C. p24 antigen: The p24 antigen is a protein associated with HIV. It is used for early detection of HIV infection but is not suitable for monitoring long-term treatment efficacy. p24 levels do not provide reliable information on viral suppression or ART effectiveness.

 

Option D. Viral serotype: Viral serotyping involves identifying different strains of HIV but does not provide information on treatment efficacy. It is more relevant in epidemiological studies and vaccine development rather than in monitoring ongoing therapy.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Viral load measurement is the most important and recommended method for monitoring the efficacy of antiretroviral therapy in HIV patients. The goal is to achieve an undetectable viral load (<50 copies/mL).

questions.text: Which of the following conditions is associated with hypokalemic metabolic alkalosis with hypertension? (INICET NOV 2021)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Liddle syndrome

 

Liddle syndrome is a genetic disorder characterized by the overactivation of the epithelial sodium channels (ENaC) in the principal cells of the kidneys. This overactivation is due to a gain-of-function mutation in the genes encoding these channels. The increased activity of ENaC leads to excessive reabsorption of sodium and water, causing hypertension. Concurrently, there is increased excretion of potassium and hydrogen ions, which results in hypokalemia and metabolic alkalosis.

 

This condition is often referred to as pseudo-hyperaldosteronism because it mimics the effects of aldosterone but without elevated aldosterone levels. The treatment of choice for Liddle syndrome is amiloride, which directly inhibits ENaC channels, unlike spironolactone, which is ineffective in this condition.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Bartter syndrome: Bartter syndrome also presents with hypokalemia and metabolic alkalosis, but patients typically have normal blood pressure. It is a group of autosomal recessive disorders that affect the thick ascending limb of the loop of Henle, mimicking the effects of loop diuretics. Symptoms often present in childhood and may include polyuria, polydipsia, and growth delays. Additionally, patients might have nephrocalcinosis due to increase urinary calcium, recurrent urinary stones, and sometimes sensorineural deafness.

 

Option C. Gitelman syndrome: Gitelman syndrome, like Bartter syndrome, involves hypokalemia and metabolic alkalosis with normal blood pressure. It affects the distal convoluted tubule of the kidney, similar to the action of thiazide diuretics. Patients usually present in adulthood with symptoms such as muscle weakness, cramps, and tetany due to hypomagnesemia, which is a significant feature distinguishing it from Bartter syndrome.

 

Option D. Gordon syndrome: Gordon syndrome, or pseudohypoaldosteronism type II, is characterized by hypertension and hyperkalemia, along with metabolic acidosis, not alkalosis. It results from mutations leading to increased sodium chloride reabsorption in the distal convoluted tubule. Unlike Liddle syndrome, patients with Gordon syndrome exhibit hyperkalemia and acidosis due to chloride retention.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Liddle syndrome is characterized by hypokalemic metabolic alkalosis and hypertension due to the overactivation of epithelial sodium channels in the kidneys.

questions.text: Definition of PUO includes all of the following except? (AIIMS MAY 2017)
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Undiagnosed after one week of investigation

 

The correct answer is C because the definition of Pyrexia of Unknown Origin (PUO) does not specify that the fever must remain undiagnosed for only one week. According to the established criteria for diagnosing PUO, the investigation can be longer and more thorough before labeling a fever as PUO. The criteria include a fever exceeding 38.3°C on at least two occasions, persisting for more than three weeks, and a diagnosis that remains uncertain after comprehensive history taking, physical examinations, and routine investigations.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Fever persisting for more than 3 weeks: This is incorrect because it is a part of the definition of PUO, where the fever must last for more than three weeks.

 

Option B. Immunocompromised status should be ruled out: This is incorrect  as a choice because being non-immunocompromised is a criterion in the diagnosis of PUO, which means any immunocompromised status should indeed be ruled out.

 

Option D. Temperature more than 38.3°C: This is also incorrect as it is part of the criteria, where the temperature must be more than 38.3°C on multiple occasions to consider it as PUO.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Criteria for diagnosis of PUO:

 

  • Fever > 38.3 degrees C (101° F) on 2 occasions.
  • Duration > 3 weeks.
  • Not immunocompromised state.
  • Diagnosis not certain after history, physical examination and routine and obligatory investigations.

questions.text: A 72-year-old man with a history of HTN, DM2, and DLP is brought to the ER because of reports of palpitations and dizziness. ECG is ordered and shown in the image. His temperature is 36.8°C, PR is 106/min, RR is 18/min, BP is 84/46 mm Hg, and SpO2 is 92% on room air. What is the next step? (FMGE JAN 2023)
questions.solution:
Ans. D) DC shock

 

The patient presents with atrial fibrillation (AF) characterized by an irregularly irregular rhythm and absence of well-defined P waves on the ECG. His vital signs indicate hemodynamic instability, specifically a low systolic blood pressure of 84 mm Hg (<90 mm HG).

 

Why DC Shock is Correct: DC shock (synchronized cardioversion) is indicated for patients with tachyarrhythmia who are hemodynamically unstable. Hemodynamic instability is evidenced by a systolic blood pressure below 90 mm Hg, which is a critical threshold indicating the need for immediate cardioversion to restore normal rhythm and improve cardiac output.

 

Steps for Decision Making:

 

  1. Identify the Rhythm: The ECG shows atrial fibrillation.
  2. Assess Stability: The patient's systolic blood pressure is 84 mm Hg, indicating instability.
  3. Treatment Protocol: Immediate synchronized cardioversion (DC shock) is necessary for unstable tachyarrhythmias.

 

Note - The three contraindications for using synchronized DC cardioversion are:

 

  1. Sinus tachycardia
  2. Multifocal atrial tachycardia
  3. Digitalis toxicity

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Heparin: Heparin is used for anticoagulation in AF to prevent thromboembolism. However, it does not address hemodynamic instability or the immediate need to correct the arrhythmia.

 

Option B. Beta blocker: Beta blockers are used for rate control in stable AF. They are inappropriate for acute management in hemodynamically unstable patients because they can further lower blood pressure and worsen instability.

 

Option C. Amiodarone: Amiodarone is an antiarrhythmic that can be used to convert AF to sinus rhythm, but it is not the first-line treatment in an unstable patient. Immediate cardioversion is preferred in this scenario.

 

Educational Objective:

 

In cases of tachyarrhythmia with hemodynamic instability (e.g., systolic BP < 90 mm Hg), immediate synchronized cardioversion (DC shock) is the treatment of choice.

 

Rule of thumb: "If the patient is in shock, shock the patient."

questions.text: Which of the following is NOT a first-line drug for the management of a patient with rheumatoid arthritis? (INICET MAY 2022)
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Azathioprine

 

The first-line drugs for the management of rheumatoid arthritis (RA) are typically Disease-Modifying Antirheumatic Drugs (DMARDs), which include sulfasalazine, hydroxychloroquine, and methotrexate. These drugs are considered core therapies and are often used together in what is known as "triple therapy."

 

Sulfasalazine, hydroxychloroquine, and methotrexate are highly effective and commonly used in the treatment of RA. They form the backbone of conventional synthetic DMARDs (csDMARDs).

 

Azathioprine, on the other hand, is not a first-line drug for RA management. While it is used in some autoimmune conditions, it is not as effective for RA as the other mentioned drugs. Its efficacy is lower, and it is not commonly included in the standard RA treatment regimens.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Sulfasalazine: This drug is a part of the core therapies for RA and is commonly used as a first-line treatment. It is known for its effectiveness and is often used in combination with other DMARDs.

 

Option B. Hydroxychloroquine: Another key first-line drug for RA, hydroxychloroquine is widely used due to its efficacy and relatively favorable safety profile. It is often part of the triple therapy regimen.

 

Option C. Methotrexate: Methotrexate is considered the cornerstone of RA treatment and is usually the first drug prescribed. It is highly effective and forms the basis of most RA treatment protocols.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Azathioprine is not a first-line drug for the management of rheumatoid arthritis; the primary first-line drugs are sulfasalazine, hydroxychloroquine, and methotrexate.

 

Note -

 

  • Sulfasalazine and Hydroxychloroquine are considered safe for use during pregnancy and are preferred in the management of RA among pregnant patients.
  • Azathioprine is also somewhat safe during pregnancy, but it is not as effective for RA, so it is less preferred compared to Sulfasalazine and Hydroxychloroquine.
  • Methotrexate and Leflunomide are not safe for use during pregnancy and should be avoided due to potential risks to the developing fetus.

 

Additional Information:

 

Rheumatoid arthritis management: Range of biological disease-modifying antirheumatic drugs (bDMARDs) and targeted synthetic disease-modifying antirheumatic drugs (tsDMARDs).

questions.text: Best provocative test for diagnosis of gastrinoma is: (NEET PG 2014)
questions.solution:
Ans. B. Secretin injection test

 

Explanation:

 

Gastrinomas, also known as Zollinger-Ellison Syndrome (ZES), are characterized by hypersecretion of gastrin by a non-beta cell tumor, leading to excessive gastric acid production and peptic ulceration. The secretin injection test is the most valuable provocative test in diagnosing ZES.

 

Why the Secretin Injection Test is the Best:

 

  • Secretin, when injected, induces a substantial increase in serum gastrin levels in patients with gastrinoma, making it the most sensitive and specific test for ZES.
  • Secretin stimulation test is preferred due to its higher sensitivity and specificity compared to other provocative tests.

 

Gastrinomas; Zollinger Ellison Syndrome Review:

 

 

Treatment of ZES:

 

  • Proton Pump Inhibitors (PPIs): Preferred treatment to control gastric acid secretion.
  • Surgical Intervention: Considered in cases where PPIs are not effective or if there are complications.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The secretin injection test is the gold standard provocative test for diagnosing gastrinoma due to its high sensitivity and specificity.

questions.text: A patient presents with frequent urination, nocturia, and enuresis. 24-hour urine volume was measured and recorded to be 7 liters. The urine osmolarity was 260 mOsm/L. ADH assay was performed and the recorded values were reported as 0.8 pg/mL. An MRI of the brain was performed and T1 weighted indicated the absence of the bright spot. What is the most likely diagnosis? (NEET PG 2018)
questions.solution:
Ans. C. Pituitary DI

 

The patient's symptoms of frequent urination, nocturia, and enuresis combined with a large urine output (7 liters) and low urine osmolarity (260 mOsm/L) suggest a deficiency in ADH effect. The low ADH level (0.8 pg/mL) and the absence of the bright spot on T1 weighted MRI (indicative of a pituitary abnormality) further support the diagnosis of Pituitary Diabetes Insipidus (DI). In Pituitary DI, ADH (vasopressin) is not adequately produced by the hypothalamus or released from the posterior pituitary, which leads to reduced water reabsorption in the kidney and subsequent polyuria.

 

Approach to Polyuria:

 

  • Water vs solute diuresis: (first thing to know)
  • Water diuresis: DI, Primary polydipsia
  • Solute diuresis:
    • Glycosuria (Hyperglycemia, SGLT2 inhibitor use)
    • Iatrogenic hyper-osmolar agents (Hypertonic saline, Mannitol, Urea - from high-protein tube feeding, Radiocontrast agents)
    • Salt wasting (e.g., Medullary cystic disease, Diuretics, CSWS, Obstructive uropathy -especially if B/L, resolving ATN)
  • Before giving desmopressin → S. Na+ should be 145(or) P. Osm should be > 295.
  • If this cannot be achieved (usually due to severe thirst) during water deprivation - Alternative for water deprivation is Hypertonic saline infusion to achieve S. Na > 145 or P. Osm > 295 - then desmopressin test can be performed.
  • Hypertonic saline (to ↑P. Osm) + Plasma AVP measurement in response to ↑ P. Osm due to hypertonic saline. Plasma AVP is unstable and needs stringent storage techniques. Based on AVP levels- can diagnose pituitary vs nephrogenic vs primary polydipsia. Diagnostic accuracy is questionable.

 

 

**Plasma Co-Peptin (analogues to C-peptide of insulin) can be used for central vs nephrogenic DI.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Nephrogenic DI: Incorrect because it typically involves normal or high levels of ADH, but the kidneys do not respond to it. The patient's ADH is low, making this diagnosis less likely.

 

Option B. Primary polydipsia: This is associated with excessive fluid intake leading to large volumes of dilute urine but generally will not affect ADH levels significantly, and the brain MRI would typically be normal.

 

Option D. Mannitol infusion: This causes an osmotic diuresis due to the mannitol not being reabsorbed in the renal tubules. There is no evidence of mannitol administration in the patient's history.

 

Educational Objective:

 

MMS algorithm for finding out the cause:

questions.text: A 23-year-old medical student with a 2-month history of palpitations, sweating, and restlessness. He also complains of a sweaty palm. His appearance is as shown in the picture. What is the next step in evaluation? (NEET PG 2023)
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Ultrasensitive thyrotropin

 

The patient's symptoms and the clinical image strongly suggest Graves' Orbitopathy (also known as Graves' Ophthalmopathy), characterized by proptosis, eyelid edema, and eye congestion. The most common cause of both unilateral and bilateral exophthalmos is Graves' disease, an autoimmune disorder leading to hyperthyroidism.

 

The next step in evaluating a patient suspected of having hyperthyroidism is to perform a thyroid function test (TFT), with the most important initial test being the measurement of Thyroid Stimulating Hormone (TSH). The ultrasensitive thyrotropin test, which measures TSH levels, is crucial because it helps in determining the presence of hyperthyroidism.

 

In Graves' disease, TSH levels are typically very low or undetectable, while free T4 and Total T3 levels are elevated (primary hyperthyroidism).

 

IOC – MRI of the orbit

 

TOC – mild – moderate disease – conservative management

 

Mod.-severe disease – first line TOC – CS (Dexamethasone); Teprotumumab (IGF1 receptor inhibitor Mab)

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Thyroid receptor antibody: This test is specific for confirming Graves' disease, but it is not the first step. It is used after initial thyroid function tests suggest hyperthyroidism to confirm the diagnosis. The antibodies known as TRAb (TSH receptor antibody/ Thyroid receptor Ab).

 

2 forms of TRAb – TSI (Thyroid Stimulating Immunoglobulin) and

                -  TBII (Thyroid binding Inhibitory Immunoglobulin)

 

Option B. Radioactive Iodine Uptake: This test helps to differentiate between various causes of hyperthyroidism, such as Graves' disease and toxic multinodular goiter. It is not the first step but follows initial thyroid function tests if hyperthyroidism is confirmed.

 

Option D. Anti thyroid peroxidase antibody: This antibody is not specific for Graves' disease. It is more commonly associated with Hashimoto's thyroiditis and other autoimmune thyroid disorders, making it less relevant for initial evaluation in this context.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The first and most crucial test in the evaluation of suspected hyperthyroidism, such as in a case suggestive of Graves' disease, is the measurement of ultrasensitive thyrotropin (TSH) levels.

 

Confirmatory Diagnosis – by TRAbs (Thyroid receptor antibodies)

questions.text: A 20-year-old woman presents with breathlessness and chest pain. She is a known case of mitral stenosis. Her pulse is irregularly irregular. No thrombus is seen on echocardiography. What can be done to prevent future thrombotic events? (NEET PG 2021)
questions.solution:
Ans. C. Oral warfarin

 

The patient is diagnosed with mitral stenosis and has an irregularly irregular pulse, indicating atrial fibrillation (AF). Atrial fibrillation is a common complication in patients with mitral stenosis and significantly increases the risk of thromboembolic events.

 

Long-term anticoagulation therapy is essential in such patients to prevent these events. The presence of mitral stenosis, particularly moderate to severe, mandates the use of oral anticoagulants. Warfarin is the recommended anticoagulant in this scenario because it is the only approved medication for patients with mitral stenosis and those with mechanical prosthetic heart valves.

 

Other anticoagulants, such as Direct Oral Anticoagulants (DOACs), are not recommended in patients with valvular atrial fibrillation (AF associated with mitral stenosis or mechanical heart valves).

 

Additional Information –

 

CHA2DS2-VASc score to guide anticoagulation therapy in patients without mitral stenosis or a prosthetic valve.

 

  • C - Congestive heart failure: 1 point
  • H - Hypertension: 1 point
  • A - Age 65 to 74: 1 point, Age 75 and above: 2 points
  • D - Diabetes Mellitus: 1 point
  • S2 - Prior stroke or TIA: 2 points
  • Sex category (Female): 1 point
  • Vascular diseases (such as coronary artery disease or peripheral artery disease): 1 point

 

Scoring and Treatment Recommendations

 

  • Total Points: Ranges from 0 to 9.
  • Score of 2 or more: Strongly indicates the need for long-term anticoagulation (DOAC > warfarin).

 

Direct Oral Anticoagulants (DOACs) such as Dabigatran, Apixaban, Rivaroxaban, or Edoxaban are preferred unless the patient has conditions like mitral stenosis or mechanical prosthetic valves, in which case Warfarin might be more appropriate.

 

  • Score less than 2: Anticoagulation may be considered but is less mandatory.

 

This scoring system is crucial for making informed decisions about anticoagulation therapy to prevent stroke in patients with atrial fibrillation, tailoring treatment based on individual risk profiles.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Dabigatran: Dabigatran is a DOAC that is not recommended for patients with mitral stenosis or mechanical heart valves. It is suitable for non-valvular atrial fibrillation but not for valvular AF.

 

Option B. Aspirin 150mg: Aspirin is not sufficient as an anticoagulant in patients with atrial fibrillation, especially those with mitral stenosis. It does not provide the necessary anticoagulation to prevent thromboembolic events in such high-risk patients.

 

Option D. Aspirin + Clopidogrel: This combination is also inadequate for anticoagulation in atrial fibrillation, particularly in patients with mitral stenosis. While it can prevent platelet aggregation, it does not provide the anticoagulation required to prevent thrombus formation in atrial fibrillation.

 

Educational Objective:

 

In patients with atrial fibrillation associated with mitral stenosis, oral warfarin is the recommended anticoagulant to prevent thromboembolic events.

questions.text: A 65-year-old chronic smoker presented with swelling of the face, difficulty breathing, and cyanosis over the upper chest and neck region. He also reported prominent veins on his chest. The chest X-ray is given below. What is the most likely diagnosis? (Twisted PYQ)
questions.solution:
Ans. C. Superior vena cava obstruction

 

Explanation:


Superior vena cava (SVC) obstruction results from compression or invasion of the SVC by a mediastinal mass, commonly caused by malignancies such as lung cancer or lymphoma. Key features include:

 

  • Swelling of the face, neck, and upper chest (venous engorgement): Due to impaired venous return to the heart.
  • Cyanosis over the upper chest and neck: Caused by venous stasis.
  • Prominent veins on the chest wall: Resulting from collateral circulation to bypass the obstructed SVC.
  • Chest X-ray findings: Often show a mediastinal mass or other signs of obstruction.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Pancoast tumor: Incorrect because while Pancoast tumors can cause local neurological symptoms (e.g., Horner's syndrome or brachial plexus involvement), they are not classically associated with SVC obstruction symptoms like facial swelling or cyanosis.

 

Option B. Upper lobe pneumonia: Incorrect because pneumonia causes consolidation and symptoms like fever and productive cough, rather than venous congestion or prominent chest veins.

 

Option D. Aspergilloma: Incorrect because aspergillomas are localized fungal balls in pre-existing cavities and do not cause symptoms of venous obstruction or facial swelling.

 

Educational Objective:


Superior vena cava obstruction is characterized by facial and upper body swelling, cyanosis, and prominent chest veins due to impaired venous drainage. It is commonly associated with malignancies compressing the SVC and can be identified on imaging as a mediastinal mass.

questions.text:
A patient presents with severe vomiting and diarrhea and has orthostatic hypotension. What metabolic abnormalities would you expect in this patient? (INICET MAY 2023)

 

1.Hypokalemia

2.Hypochloremia

3.Metabolic alkalosis

4.Respiratory alkalosis
questions.solution:
Ans. D) 1, 2, 3

 

Severe vomiting and diarrhea can lead to multiple metabolic abnormalities: Hypokalemia, Hypochloremia, metabolic alkalosis with hyponatremia.

 

1. Hypokalemia: Loss of potassium through vomiting and diarrhea.

 

2. Hypochloremia: Loss of chloride.

 

3. Metabolic alkalosis: Loss of gastric acids.

 

These changes are due to the loss of electrolytes and fluids.

 

Other Option:

 

4. Respiratory alkalosis involves hyperventilation and a decrease in carbon dioxide, which is unrelated to the described condition.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Severe vomiting and diarrhea typically cause hypokalemia, hypochloremia, and metabolic alkalosis.

choices.text: First degree of heart block

questions.text: Disappearance of loud S1 in mitral stenosis occurs in all except: (AIIMS NOV 2018)
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Mild MS.

 

Loud S1 can be heard in mild MS also because loud S1 does not depend on severity of MS.

 

Loud S1 is one of the auscultatory hallmarks of MS, however it can be attenuated in a variety of conditions:

 

  • Associated MR
  • Long PR (first degree heart block)
  • CCF
  • Severe AR- regurgitant jet may impinge on AML
  • Calcified valve

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. First degree heart block: Here, the prolonged PR interval delays the closure of the mitral valve relative to ventricular contraction, often softening or eliminating the loud S1.

 

Option B. AR (Aortic Regurgitation): The regurgitant flow in aortic regurgitation can prevent the mitral valve leaflets from closing tightly and sharply, thus softening the S1.

 

Option C. Calcified valve: Calcification of the mitral valve leads to stiffening of the leaflets, which inhibits their rapid movement and thus reduces the intensity of S1.

 

Educational Objective:

 

In mitral stenosis, a loud S1 is typically present unless there is an associated condition that affects the mobility or timing of the mitral valve leaflet closure, such as calcification, regurgitation in other valves, or disturbances in electrical conduction that affect heart rhythm

questions.text: Which of the following is seen in LMN (Lower Motor Neuron) weakness? (Twisted PYQ)
questions.solution:
Ans. A. Fasciculations

 

Explanation:


Lower Motor Neuron (LMN) lesions result from damage to the motor neurons that directly innervate skeletal muscles. Key features include:

 

  • Fasciculations: Visible involuntary contractions of muscle fibers caused by spontaneous firing of denervated motor units, a hallmark of LMN lesions.
  • Muscle atrophy: Prominent due to denervation and lack of use.
  • Hypotonia and hypo-reflexia: Decreased muscle tone and diminished deep tendon reflexes due to the loss of excitatory input to the reflex arc.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Hyper-reflexia: Incorrect because hyper-reflexia is a hallmark of UMN lesions, not LMN lesions, due to loss of cortical inhibitory control.

 

Option C. Spasticity: Incorrect because spasticity (velocity-dependent increase in muscle tone) is characteristic of UMN lesions.

 

Option D. Babinski sign: Incorrect because the Babinski sign is a finding of UMN lesions, where there is an upgoing big toe on plantar stimulation, absent in LMN lesions.

 

Educational Objective:


Fasciculations are a hallmark feature of LMN lesions, distinguishing them from UMN lesions, which are characterized by hyper-reflexia, spasticity, and the Babinski sign. LMN lesions result in muscle atrophy and reduced reflexes due to loss of neuronal input to muscles.

questions.text: Auenbrugger’s sign is seen in: (NEET PG 2017)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Pericardial Effusion

 

Explanation:

 

Auenbrugger's sign refers to dullness in the left posterior lung field (at the base) that is seen in patients with large pericardial effusions. This is also known as Ewart's sign. When the pericardium expands due to fluid accumulation, it causes minicollapse and dullness in the left posterior lung field, which can be detected on percussion examination. This physical finding is characteristic of significant pericardial effusions.

 

 Other Options: 

 

Option B. Constrictive Pericarditis: Constrictive pericarditis presents with signs of right heart failure, increased JVP with prominent x and y descent, pericardial knock, and Kussmaul's sign (no respiratory variation of JVP). Auenbrugger's sign is not a feature of constrictive pericarditis.

 

Option C. Aortic Regurgitation: Aortic regurgitation typically presents with wide pulse pressure, diastolic murmur, and signs of left ventricular volume overload. Auenbrugger's sign is not associated with this valvular condition.

 

Option D. Mitral Stenosis: Mitral stenosis typically presents with symptoms of pulmonary congestion, a diastolic murmur, and possible atrial fibrillation. Auenbrugger's sign is not a feature of mitral stenosis.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Auenbrugger's sign (also known as Ewart's sign) is a physical finding characterized by dullness in the left posterior lung field due to compression by an enlarged pericardium in patients with large pericardial effusions.

questions.text: A 10-year-old child presents with brown-colored urine, generalized edema, and fatigue for the last 5 days. Investigations reveal 4+ proteinuria, hypoalbuminemia, and no red blood cells on microscopy. What is the most likely diagnosis? (Twisted PYQ)
questions.solution:
Answer: D. Minimal change disease

 

Explanation:


Minimal change disease (MCD) is the most likely diagnosis based on the following:

  • Brown-colored urine: May result from concentrated proteinuria rather than hematuria.
  • Generalized edema: A hallmark of nephrotic syndrome caused by hypoalbuminemia and low oncotic pressure.
  • 4+ proteinuria and hypoalbuminemia: These findings are classic for nephrotic syndrome, commonly associated with MCD in children.
  • No red blood cells: This rules out hematuria of glomerular origin, such as in post-streptococcal glomerulonephritis.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Post-streptococcal glomerulonephritis: Incorrect because PSGN typically presents with hematuria (dysmorphic RBCs), moderate proteinuria, and no significant hypoalbuminemia or edema unless nephrotic syndrome overlaps.

 

Option B. Urinary tract infection: Incorrect because UTI is usually associated with pyuria, bacteriuria, and isomorphic RBCs, not heavy proteinuria or hypoalbuminemia.

 

Option C. Bladder calculi: Incorrect because bladder calculi typically present with hematuria (isomorphic RBCs) and symptoms like dysuria or frequency, not nephrotic-range proteinuria or hypoalbuminemia.

 

Educational Objective:


Minimal change disease is a common cause of nephrotic syndrome in children, characterized by heavy proteinuria, hypoalbuminemia, and generalized edema. It typically lacks hematuria, distinguishing it from glomerulonephritis.

questions.text: An old man has recurrent fainting episodes. His ECG shows P-waves at 75/min, QRS complexes are at 35 bpm. The clinical diagnosis is: (FMGE JANUARY 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Stokes-Adams Syndrome

 

The patient has recurrent fainting episodes, and his ECG shows a discrepancy between the rate of P-waves (75/min) and QRS complexes (35 bpm), indicating an AV block.

 

In this case, the P-waves are getting blocked at the AV node, leading to fewer QRS complexes.

 

Stokes-Adams Syndrome refers to recurrent fainting/ syncopal episodes caused by sudden fluctuations in cardiac output, paroxysmal Bradycardia often due to AV blocks such as complete heart block or second-degree AV block (Mobitz type II).

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Electrical alternans: This is seen in cardiac tamponade and is characterized by beat-to-beat variations in QRS amplitude or axis. The patient would present with signs of tamponade such as hypotension, muffled heart sounds, and jugular venous distension, which is not the case here.

 

Option B. Atrial tachycardia: This would present with a ventricular response rate of more than 100 bpm and would typically involve abnormal P-wave morphology. The patient in this case has bradycardia (QRS at 35 bpm), excluding atrial tachycardia.

 

Option C. First degree AV block: This is characterized by a prolonged PR interval with a 1:1 P to QRS ratio. The discrepancy between P-wave and QRS complex rates in this case excludes first degree AV block.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Stokes-Adams Syndrome involves recurrent fainting episodes due to sudden changes in cardiac output, typically from AV block-related bradycardia. Recognizing the discrepancy between atrial and ventricular rates is crucial for diagnosis.

questions.text: A patient in emergency has the following lab parameters: creatinine 1.5 and BUN 45. The chest x-ray is shown below. In gram staining and culture only, rhinovirus was isolated. The patient is shifted to ICU. What is the treatment of choice in this patient? (INICET MAY 2023)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Ceftriaxone plus azithromycin

 

The patient is diagnosed with community-acquired pneumonia (CAP) and has been shifted to the ICU. The treatment of choice for ICU-admitted patients with CAP includes a beta-lactam antibiotic like beta-lactam/beta-lactamase inhibitor (BL/BLI) combination like amoxicillin-clavulanic acid or piperacillin-tazobactam, or a third-generation cephalosporin like ceftriaxone combined with azithromycin or a respiratory fluoroquinolone such as levofloxacin or moxifloxacin should be administered.

 

Ceftriaxone are used to cover typical bacteria, while azithromycin covers atypical bacteria and provides additional anti-inflammatory properties.

 

Other Options:
 

Option A. Azithromycin: Insufficient as monotherapy in ICU settings.
 

Option C. Amoxicillin plus clavulanic acid: Lacks coverage for atypical pathogens alone.
 

Option D. Piperacillin Tazobactam plus ciprofloxacin: Ciprofloxacin is not a respiratory fluoroquinolone.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The combination of a beta-lactam antibiotic and azithromycin is the treatment of choice for ICU-admitted patients with community-acquired pneumonia.

choices.text: Aspergillus Niger - Voriconazole
Aspergillus fumigatus - Micafungin
Candida albicans - Amphotericin B
Candida Krusei– Fluconazole

questions.text: Identify the correct 'organism-drug to which it is intrinsically resistant' pair: (INICET MAY 2021)
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Candida Krusei- Fluconazole

 

Candida Krusei is known to be intrinsically resistant to fluconazole, which is a widely used antifungal agent. This resistance is due to the specific genetic and biochemical characteristics of C. Kruse, which include efflux pumps that actively expel the drug and alterations in the target enzyme of fluconazole, making it less effective.

 

Other Options:
 

Option A. Aspergillus Niger - Voriconazole: Aspergillus Niger is not intrinsically resistant to voriconazole; in fact, voriconazole is one of the treatments of choice for Aspergillus infections.

 

Option B. Aspergillus fumigatus - Micafungin: Aspergillus fumigatus is sensitive to echinocandins, including micafungin. It is not intrinsically resistant to this drug.

 

Option C. Candida albicans - Amphotericin B: Candida albicans is sensitive to amphotericin B, which is a broad-spectrum antifungal with a wide range of activity against various fungal species.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Candida Krusei is intrinsically resistant to fluconazole.

questions.text: Among the given options, murmur given in the image is associated with? (NEET PG 2023)
questions.solution:
Ans. B. Mitral Regurgitation

 

The image provided indicates a murmur occurring between S1 and S2, which is described as a pan-systolic murmur. This type of murmur spans the entirety of systole.

 

Mitral Regurgitation produces a pan-systolic murmur due to the backward flow of blood from the left ventricle into the left atrium throughout systole.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Aortic Regurgitation: Characterized by an early diastolic murmur due to backflow of blood from the aorta into the left ventricle.

 

Option C. Mitral Stenosis: Characterized by a mid-diastolic murmur due to obstructed blood flow from the left atrium to the left ventricle during diastole.

 

Option D. Aortic Stenosis: Characterized by an ejection systolic murmur due to turbulent blood flow across a narrowed aortic valve during systole.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Mitral regurgitation is associated with a pan-systolic murmur, which is present throughout the systole and heard between the S1 and S2 heart sounds.

questions.text: Large bowel colonic diarrhea is associated with all of the following, except: (NEET PG 2014)
questions.solution:
Ans. A. Large volume stool

 

Explanation:

 

Large bowel colonic diarrhea is typically associated with frequent, small-volume stools due to the reduced reservoir capacity of the colon. The other associated features include urgency, tenesmus, and mucus in the stool. In contrast, large-volume stools are characteristic of small bowel (right-sided) diarrhea.

 

Right-Sided (Small Bowel) Diarrhea:

  • Reservoir Capacity: Intact
  • Stool Volume: Large
  • Increase in Number of Stools: Modest
  • Urgency: Absent
  • Tenesmus: Absent
  • Mucus: Absent
  • Blood: Absent
  • Proctosigmoidoscopy: Usually Normal
  • Mechanism: Non-Specific

 

Left-Sided (Large Bowel) Diarrhea:

  • Reservoir Capacity: Decreased
  • Stool Volume: Small
  • Increase in Number of Stools: Large
  • Urgency: Present
  • Tenesmus: Present
  • Mucus: Present
  • Blood: Present
  • Proctosigmoidoscopy: Usually Confirms Inflammation
  • Mechanism: Usually Exudative

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Urgency: Urgency is a common symptom of large bowel colonic diarrhea due to inflammation and reduced reservoir capacity.

 

Option C. Tenesmus: Tenesmus, a sensation of incomplete evacuation, is also common in large bowel colonic diarrhea.

 

Option D. Mucus: Mucus in the stool is typically present in large bowel colonic diarrhea, indicating inflammation.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Large bowel colonic diarrhea is characterized by frequent, small-volume stools, urgency, tenesmus, and mucus. Large-volume stools are not associated with large bowel colonic diarrhea but are seen in small bowel (right-sided) diarrhea.

questions.text: A 65-year-old female patient is brought to the ER in a state of unconsciousness. Her BP is 70/50 mm of Hg and her ECG is shown below. What is the next best step in the management of her condition? (NEET PG 2019)
questions.solution:
Ans. D. Synchronized cardioversion

 

Any hemodynamically unstable rhythm, requires synchronized cardioversion (Shock delivered in sync with R wave to prevent R-on-T phenomenon)

 

Other Options:

 

Option A: AV Nodal blockers are used if hemodynamically stable.

 

Option B: Maximum of 30mg of adenosine can be tried if patient is Hemodynamically Stable.

 

Option C: Carotid massage is not recommended for hemodynamically unstable patient.

 

Educational Objective:

questions.text: A 45-year-old patient presented with weakness and fatigue. Lab reports showed low Hb and high reticulocyte count. WBC and platelet counts were normal. What is the likely diagnosis? (FMGE JULY 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Hemolytic anemia

 

The presence of a high reticulocyte count in the context of anemia indicates that the bone marrow is responding appropriately by producing more red blood cells to compensate for the anemia. This is a typical finding in hemolytic anemia, where there is increased destruction of red blood cells in the periphery, leading to an increase in reticulocyte production as the bone marrow attempts to replace the lost cells.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Anemia of chronic disease: This type of anemia is typically characterized by a low reticulocyte count due to impaired erythropoiesis in response to chronic inflammation or disease.

 

Option B. Aplastic crisis: In aplastic crisis, there is a failure of the bone marrow to produce sufficient blood cells, leading to low reticulocyte counts, along with low white blood cell and platelet counts.

 

Option D. Pernicious anemia: This is caused by vitamin B12 deficiency, leading to impaired DNA synthesis and resulting in megaloblastic anemia. It typically presents with low reticulocyte counts and can also affect white blood cells and platelets, causing pancytopenia.

 

Educational Objective:

 

In cases of anemia with a high reticulocyte count and normal white blood cell and platelet counts, hemolytic anemia is the likely diagnosis, indicating increased peripheral destruction of red blood cells and a compensatory increase in reticulocyte production by the bone marrow.

questions.text: A chronic alcoholic male patient presents with abdominal distension, reduced urine output, and pedal edema. His serum creatinine was 1.6 mg/dL. What is the next line of management in this patient? (NEET PG 2021)
questions.solution:
Ans. D. Terlipressin plus albumin

 

The patient described has cirrhosis with signs of renal dysfunction, which suggests the possibility of hepatorenal syndrome (HRS) (Remember - HRS is the diagnosis of exclusion)

 

HRS is a type of renal failure that occurs in patients with advanced liver disease and is characterized by functional renal failure due to reduced renal blood flow.

 

The initial management for suspected HRS involves stopping all diuretics, as they can exacerbate renal dysfunction.

 

The mainstay of treatment includes the administration of albumin to expand plasma volume and vasoconstrictors to improve renal blood flow. Terlipressin is a vasoconstrictor that is commonly used in combination with albumin to manage HRS. This combination helps to improve renal function by counteracting the splanchnic vasodilation that occurs in cirrhosis, thereby increasing effective arterial blood volume and renal perfusion.

 

Doses – The prescribed dose of albumin is 1 gram per kilogram of body weight per day. The maximum dose should not exceed 100 grams per day. Albumin should be administered for at least 48 hours, equivalent to 2 days.

 

It's important to avoid using normal saline or lactated solutions concurrently because they contain sodium, which could be contraindicated or undesirable in the treatment circumstances requiring albumin.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Methylprednisolone: Methylprednisolone is a corticosteroid and is not indicated in the treatment of hepatorenal syndrome. It is used for conditions such as autoimmune hepatitis or severe alcoholic hepatitis, but it does not address the pathophysiology of HRS.

 

Option B. Heparin: Heparin is an anticoagulant and is not appropriate in this setting due to the increased risk of bleeding in patients with cirrhosis. It is used for preventing or treating thrombotic conditions but does not play a role in managing HRS.

 

Option C. Torsemide: Torsemide is a loop diuretic and should be discontinued in patients with HRS. Diuretics can worsen renal function in these patients by further decreasing renal perfusion and exacerbating the underlying problem of splanchnic vasodilation and renal vasoconstriction.

 

Educational Objective:

 

In patients with cirrhosis and suspected hepatorenal syndrome, the appropriate management includes the use of albumin combined with vasoconstrictors like terlipressin to improve renal function and address the underlying hemodynamic changes associated with HRS.

questions.text: A 27-year-old female patient presents with weight loss, anxiety, tachycardia, and restlessness. The resting pulse was 110 beats per minute. Which of the following tests should be done next to evaluate her condition further? (INICET Nov 2023)
questions.solution:
Ans. D) TSH

 

Explanation:

 

In the evaluation of suspected thyroid dysfunction, the initial and most crucial test is the measurement of Thyroid-Stimulating Hormone (TSH). TSH is the most sensitive indicator of thyroid function because even minor changes in thyroid hormone levels cause significant changes in TSH levels due to the feedback mechanism between the thyroid gland and the pituitary gland. Elevated or suppressed TSH levels provide clear insight into whether the thyroid gland is underactive (hypothyroidism) or overactive (hyperthyroidism). Given the patient's symptoms of weight loss, anxiety, tachycardia, and restlessness, hyperthyroidism is suspected, making TSH the appropriate initial test.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A.  Total T3: T3 levels can be influenced by various factors and are usually measured after initial TSH and Free T4 tests suggest hyperthyroidism.

 

Option B.  Thyroid Scan: This imaging test evaluates thyroid structure and function, useful in cases where nodules or hyperactivity need to be assessed. It is not the first-line test for evaluating general thyroid function.

 

Option C. Free T4: Free T4 is important in assessing thyroid function and is typically measured alongside TSH. However, TSH is preferred as the initial screening test due to its sensitivity in detecting thyroid dysfunction.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The initial test for evaluating suspected thyroid dysfunction, particularly in hyperthyroid symptoms, is TSH due to its sensitivity and reliability in reflecting thyroid status.

questions.text: A patient is brought to the OPD with complaints of difficulty repeating sentences accurately, despite fluent speech and good comprehension. The family reports that these symptoms began suddenly. Which type of aphasia does the patient most likely have? (Twisted PYQ)
questions.solution:
Ans. D. Conduction aphasia

 

Explanation:


Conduction aphasia is characterized by the following:

  • Fluent speech: The patient can speak fluently without hesitation.
  • Good comprehension: The ability to understand spoken language is intact.
  • Impaired repetition: The hallmark feature of conduction aphasia is difficulty repeating sentences, caused by damage to the arcuate fasciculus, which connects Wernicke’s area (comprehension) and Broca’s area (speech production).

 

Other Options:

 

Option A: Sensory aphasia: Incorrect because sensory aphasia (Wernicke's aphasia) is characterized by impaired comprehension and nonsensical speech, which is not consistent with this patient’s preserved comprehension.

 

Option B: Motor aphasia: Incorrect because motor aphasia (Broca's aphasia) involves non-fluent, halting speech and intact comprehension, which does not fit the described fluency in this case.

 

Option C: Anomic aphasia: Incorrect because anomic aphasia primarily involves difficulty in naming objects, without the prominent repetition issues seen here.

 

Educational Objective:


Conduction aphasia is caused by damage to the arcuate fasciculus, resulting in fluent speech, intact comprehension, and impaired ability to repeat sentences. This differentiates it from sensory (Wernicke’s) and motor (Broca’s) aphasias.

questions.text: A 55-year-old man presented with chest pain and shortness of breath. An ECG was taken in the emergency and was shown. What is the likely diagnosis?  (INICET MAY 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Posterior MI

 

The patient's ECG shows classic signs of a posterior myocardial infarction (MI). The characteristic features of posterior MI in leads V1, V2 and (±) V3 include a tall R wave, ST depression, and upright T wave. These features suggest a mirror image of an infarction in the posterior wall of the left ventricle.
