While definitive diagnosis of a posterior MI typically involves additional leads (V7, V8, V9), the observed patterns in leads V2 and V3 are indicative of this condition.

 

In the provided case, the absence of ST elevation rules out an acute STEMI. NSTEMI and unstable angina can only be differentiated by cardiac biomarkers such as troponins, which are not mentioned here. Acute myocarditis would typically present with non-specific ECG changes and a relevant clinical history, such as a recent viral infection, which is not present in this scenario.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. NSTEMI:  NSTEMI (Non-ST Elevation Myocardial Infarction) can present with similar symptoms but requires positive cardiac troponins for diagnosis. The absence of troponin data makes this diagnosis less likely.

 

Option B. Unstable Angina: Unstable angina presents with similar symptoms but without elevation of cardiac biomarkers. As mentioned, differentiating between NSTEMI and unstable angina is not possible without troponin levels, which are not provided.

 

Option D. Acute Myocarditis: Acute myocarditis would typically present with a history of viral infection and can show non-specific ECG changes, often including sinus tachycardia. The patient's history and ECG findings do not support this diagnosis.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The presence of tall R waves, ST depression, and upright T waves in leads V2 and V3 are indicative of a posterior myocardial infarction.

choices.text: There is an incremental response on 2-3 Hz nerve stimulation
Antibodies are directed against voltage-gated calcium channels (VGCC)

questions.text: Which of the following statements about Lambert-Eaton Myasthenic Syndrome (LEMS) is NOT correct? (NEET PG 2015)
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: A. There is an incremental response on 2-3 Hz nerve stimulation

 

Explanation:

 

Lambert-Eaton Myasthenic Syndrome (LEMS) is a presynaptic disorder of the neuromuscular junction. In LEMS, at low rates of repetitive nerve stimulation (2-3 Hz), a decremental response is observed, similar to myasthenia gravis. However, at high rates of stimulation (20-50 Hz) or following brief exercise, an incremental response occurs, which is characteristic of LEMS. This distinguishes LEMS from myasthenia gravis. LEMS is caused by autoantibodies directed against P/Q-type calcium channels at motor nerve terminals, which impair acetylcholine release.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Antibodies are directed against voltage: gated calcium channels (VGCC) - This statement is correct. LEMS is caused by autoantibodies directed against P/Q-type calcium channels at the motor nerve terminals, detected in approximately 85% of LEMS patients. These autoantibodies impair the release of acetylcholine from nerve terminals.

 

Option C. Reflexes are absent or depressed: This statement is correct. In LEMS, patients have depressed or absent reflexes, which is a distinguishing feature from myasthenia gravis.

 

Option D. Patients experience autonomic changes: This statement is correct. LEMS patients experience autonomic changes such as dry mouth and impotence, which are characteristic features of the condition.

 

Educational Objective:

 

In LEMS, a decremental response occurs at low rates of nerve stimulation (2-3 Hz), while an incremental response is seen at high rates of stimulation (20-50 Hz) or after brief exercise—this electrophysiologic pattern helps distinguish LEMS from myasthenia gravis.

questions.text: A 35-year-old female presents with daytime sleepiness, impaired concentration, and impaired memory. On exam, her BMI is 43, BP is 170/100 mm Hg. Her daytime ABG analysis shows HCO3 - 33 mEq/L, PaCO2 - 53 mmHg, and PaO2 - 70 mmHg. What is the most likely diagnosis? (FMGE JULY 2023)
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Obesity hypoventilation syndrome

 

Explanation:

 

The patient has obesity hypoventilation syndrome (OHS), which is characterized by the following criteria:

 

  • A BMI of 30 or more, indicating obesity.
  • Hypercarbia or hypercapnia, defined as PaCO2 > 45 mm Hg.
  • The awake ABG must be taken (daytime ABG).
  • No other causes (central or peripheral neuromuscular) should be present to explain the hypercapnia.

 

The patient's symptoms and test results align with OHS. OHS patients typically present with symptoms like daytime sleepiness, impaired concentration, and impaired memory, which are noted in this patient.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Obstructive sleep apnea: This condition typically causes issues during sleep, not in the daytime. It is characterized by repeated episodes of partial or complete upper airway obstruction during sleep.

 

Option B. Narcolepsy: This is a sleep disorder characterized by excessive daytime sleepiness and sudden sleep attacks, but it does not align with the patient’s clinical picture, which includes specific ABG results and severe obesity.

 

Option D. Central sleep apnea: Like obstructive sleep apnea, central sleep apnea occurs during sleep and involves periods of non-breathing. It does not match the daytime ABG findings of this patient.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Obesity hypoventilation syndrome is diagnosed based on a BMI of 30 or more, daytime hypercapnia (PaCO2 > 45 mm Hg), and the absence of other causes for hypercapnia.

questions.text: An old man presents with dyspnea and swelling of his feet. On examination, rales are heard and he is found to have an enlarged heart on chest x-ray. Which of the following will delay the progression?
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Captopril

 

Explanation:

 

Captopril, an ACE inhibitor, has been shown to improve survival and delay the progression of heart failure. ACE inhibitors like Captopril work by blocking the conversion of angiotensin I to angiotensin II, leading to vasodilation and reduced workload on the heart. This class of drugs is considered a cornerstone in the management of heart failure with reduced ejection fraction (HF-REF). The benefits of ACE inhibitors in heart failure are well-documented, including the 1992 study on Enalapril, which demonstrated its effectiveness as a gold standard treatment.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Furosemide: A loop diuretic, Furosemide is effective in reducing symptoms of congestion and decreasing heart failure hospitalization rates but does not improve survival or delay disease progression.

 

Option B. Carvedilol: While Carvedilol, a non-selective beta-blocker, has mortality benefits and improves survival in heart failure patients, it is not preferred over ACE inhibitors as the first choice for delaying heart failure progression.

 

Option C. Digoxin: This medication can reduce symptoms and heart failure hospitalizations to some extent, particularly in advanced heart failure, but it does not delay disease progression or improve survival, as evidenced by trials like the DIG trial.

 

Educational Objective:

 

ACE inhibitors, such as Captopril, are essential in delaying the progression of heart failure and improving survival.

choices.text: Negative skin tuberculin test and negative chest X-ray
Positive skin tuberculin test and positive chest X-ray
Positive skin tuberculin test and negative chest X-ray
Negative skin tuberculin test and positive chest X-ray

questions.text: 65-year-old male presented with unexplained fever and prolonged respiratory distress despite appropriate treatment. A diagnosis of cryptic TB was made. Which of the following is the correct statement related to this condition? (FMGE JAN 2023)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Negative skin tuberculin test and negative chest X-ray

 

Cryptic TB is a form of disseminated miliary tuberculosis commonly seen in the elderly population. The term "cryptic" means hidden, indicating that the disease does not present with obvious clinical signs typically associated with TB. This includes a negative skin tuberculin test and no visible evidence of TB on a chest X-ray.

 

Microbiological confirmation of TB in these patients is challenging and often not possible with standard imaging techniques. Modern guidelines suggest using advanced imaging modalities like PET CT scans to detect enlarged lymph nodes in thoracic or abdominal areas, which can be sampled for confirmation. However, even with these methods, microbiological diagnosis is still difficult (DD – Malignancy).

 

In such cases, empirical anti-tubercular treatment is started, and diagnosis is confirmed based on the patient's response to therapy and resolution of symptoms and lymph node enlargement over time.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Positive skin tuberculin test and positive chest X-ray: Incorrect. Cryptic TB does not typically present with a positive skin tuberculin test or obvious chest X-ray findings. The hidden nature of this form of TB means both tests are likely to be negative.

 

Option C. Positive skin tuberculin test and negative chest X-ray: Incorrect. As mentioned, cryptic TB results in a negative skin tuberculin test, not a positive one, because the disease does not produce a strong immune response detectable by this test.

 

Option D. Negative skin tuberculin test and positive chest X-ray: Incorrect. Cryptic TB is characterized by a lack of clear imaging evidence of TB, making a positive chest X-ray an unlikely finding.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Cryptic TB is a form of disseminated tuberculosis common in the elderly, characterized by a negative skin tuberculin test and no obvious imaging evidence of TB. Diagnosis is often confirmed through empirical treatment and advanced imaging techniques.

choices.text: Systemic sclerosis of the diffuse cutaneous type
Connective tissue disease of the mixed type

questions.text: Which of the following conditions is most strongly associated with the presence of anti-centromere antibodies? (NEET PG 2015)
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: C. Syndrome characterized by CREST features.

 

Explanation: 

 

Anti-centromere antibodies are highly specific for limited cutaneous systemic sclerosis (lcSSc), which is classically associated with the CREST syndrome (Calcinosis cutis, Raynaud's phenomenon, Esophageal dysmotility, Sclerodactyly, and Telangiectasia). These antibodies show a strong association with clinical features including digital ischemic ulcers, calcinosis cutis, and isolated pulmonary arterial hypertension (PAH), while renal crisis is rarely seen in patients with this antibody pattern. Anti-centromere antibodies display a discrete speckled (centromere) pattern on immunofluorescence testing.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Systemic sclerosis of the diffuse cutaneous type: Diffuse cutaneous systemic sclerosis (dcSSc) is associated with anti-topoisomerase I (Scl-70) and anti-RNA polymerase III antibodies, not anti-centromere antibodies. These antibody patterns are mutually exclusive in systemic sclerosis.

 

Option B. Connective tissue disease of the mixed type: Mixed connective tissue disease (MCTD) is characterized by the presence of U1-RNP antibodies. Anti-centromere antibodies are not a serological feature of MCTD.

 

Option D. Inflammatory myopathy, particularly polymyositis: PM/Scl and anti-Jo antibodies are the serological markers associated with myositis overlap syndromes. Anti-centromere antibodies are not typically found in inflammatory myopathies.

 

Educational Objective: 

 

Anti-centromere antibodies have high specificity for limited cutaneous systemic sclerosis (lcSSc) and the CREST variant, serving as important serological markers that help distinguish this clinical phenotype from other forms of systemic sclerosis and connective tissue disorders.

choices.text: Intravenous fluids with S.C. long-acting insulin
Intravenous fluids with S.C. regular insulin
Intravenous fluids with I.V. regular insulin

questions.text: A patient with diabetes mellitus for the past 5 years presents with vomiting and abdominal pain. She is non-compliant with medication and appears dehydrated. Investigations revealed a blood sugar value of 500 mg/dL and the presence of ketone bodies. What is the next best step in management? (Neet pg 2022)
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Intravenous fluids with I.V. regular insulin

 

In a patient presenting with diabetic ketoacidosis (DKA), the immediate management involves FLIP Therapy (fluid resuscitation, insulin therapy and Potassium management). This patient's blood glucose is significantly elevated, and the presence of ketones indicates DKA, which is a medical emergency.

 

1. Fluids: The initial step is to administer intravenous (IV) fluids to correct dehydration and stabilize the patient's hemodynamic status. The typical approach involves giving isotonic saline (0.9% sodium chloride) at a rate of 10-20 mL/kg/hr (2-3L) for the first 2-3 hours. This helps to correct hypovolemia, improve perfusion, and begin to lower blood glucose levels.

 

Criteria for fluid management: After the initial two to three hours of treatment, switch from initial fluids (typically normal saline) to half normal saline for ongoing maintenance. If capillary blood glucose (CBG) drops below 300 mg/dL, and specifically if it falls below 250 mg/dL, add 5% dextrose water to the regimen. The purpose of adding dextrose is to maintain a target CBG range of 200 to 300 mg/dL. This range helps prevent hypoglycemia, which is a critical concern in the management process.

 

2. Insulin: Insulin therapy is crucial to halt ketogenesis and reduce blood glucose levels. After 1 hr of fluid start insulin. The recommended protocol for DKA involves IV regular insulin because of its rapid onset and short duration of action. The insulin regimen follows a fixed dose insulin infusion (FDII) approach. This helps to normalize blood glucose and ketone levels efficiently.

 

First option: Continuous infusion at 0.15 units/kg/hour.

 

Second option (more commonly used): Administer a 0.1 units/kg bolus, followed by a 0.1 units/kg/hour infusion.

 

IV regular insulin is preferred over subcutaneous (SC) insulin in emergency settings like DKA due to its predictable absorption and ability to be titrated easily based on frequent blood glucose monitoring.

 

Adjustments Based on Blood Glucose Levels: Monitor capillary blood glucose (CBG). If CBG drops below 300 mg/dL, reduce the insulin infusion to half the dose (0.05 units/kg/hour).

 

Criteria for Stopping Insulin Infusion: Insulin infusion can be stopped ONLY when the patient tolerates oral feeds without vomiting or abdominal pain. Other criteria include resolution of ketoacidosis, negative or trace positive plasma ketones, and an anion gap less than 12, pH more than 7.3 and serum bicarbonate more than 18. Transition to subcutaneous insulin upon meeting these criteria.

 

Potassium Management: Potassium addition is tailored based on serum potassium levels. When serum potassium levels are within a normal range, add approximately 40 milliequivalents of potassium chloride (KCL) per liter of IV fluid administered. This ensures adequate potassium levels to prevent hypokalemia.

 

Monitoring

 

  • If serum potassium is below 3.3, administer IV potassium chloride (KCL) before insulin to prevent hypokalemia-induced arrhythmias.
  • If serum potassium is between 3.3 and 5.2, administer insulin and KCL together.
  • If serum potassium exceeds 5.3 & above, administer insulin without KCL and monitor serum potassium closely.

 

Treatment Goals and Precautions:

 

  • Aim for a target CBG of 200 to 300 mg/dL to avoid hypoglycemia.
  • The common causes of death in patients with DKA, particularly during the treatment phase – 
    • Cerebral edema (MC) may occur due to a rapid decrease in blood glucose levels, which can lead to an osmotic shift. This shift causes fluids to move from the extracellular fluid (ECF) to the intracellular fluid (ICF), resulting in swelling of the brain tissue.
    • 2nd MC cause is Potassium Disorder esp. Hypokalemia, this can result in ventricular arrythmias.
    • Other causes include ARDS, patients can initially develop acute kidney injury (pre-renal), later if severe, leads to ATN (Acute tubular necrosis) due to hypoperfusion of kidneys.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Intravenous fluids with S.C. long-acting insulin: Long-acting insulin is not suitable for acute management due to its prolonged action and delayed onset, making it inappropriate for rapid correction of hyperglycemia and ketonemia.

 

Option B. Intravenous fluids with S.C. regular insulin: While regular insulin is appropriate, the subcutaneous route is less effective in severe DKA where IV administration allows for better control and titration.

 

Option C. Intravenous insulin I.V. long-acting insulin: Long-acting insulin is never administered IV due to the risk of prolonged hypoglycemia and lack of titratability. It is also not designed for acute management settings.

 

Educational Objective:

 

In the management of diabetic ketoacidosis (DKA), the initial steps involve aggressive IV fluid resuscitation followed by IV regular insulin to rapidly lower blood glucose and resolve ketosis.

questions.text: A 10-year-old child presents with brown-colored urine, flank pain, and fatigue for the last 3 days. He has 2+ proteinuria with >20 red cells/HPF and dysmorphic red blood cells. What is the most likely diagnosis? (FMGE July 2023)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Post-streptococcal glomerulonephritis

 

Explanation:

 

The clinical presentation of a 10-year-old child with brown-colored urine, flank pain, fatigue, significant proteinuria, and dysmorphic red blood cells suggests a diagnosis of glomerulonephritis. Among the given options, the most likely diagnosis is Post-streptococcal glomerulonephritis (PSGN). Key points supporting this diagnosis include:

 

  • Brown-colored urine (tea or cola colored): Indicates hematuria.
  • Flank pain and fatigue: Common symptoms associated with glomerulonephritis.
  • Proteinuria and dysmorphic red blood cells: Indicate glomerular origin of hematuria, typical in glomerulonephritis.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Urinary tract infection: Usually presents with isomorphic red blood cells rather than dysmorphic red blood cells and would typically be associated with symptoms of urinary frequency, urgency, and dysuria.

 

Option C. Bladder calculi: Can cause hematuria but typically produces isomorphic red blood cells, not dysmorphic ones.

 

Option D. Minimal change disease: Usually presents with nephrotic syndrome, characterized by heavy proteinuria, hypoalbuminemia, edema, and frothy urine, rather than hematuria and dysmorphic red blood cells.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Post-streptococcal glomerulonephritis is a common cause of glomerulonephritis in children, presenting with hematuria, proteinuria, and dysmorphic red blood cells following a streptococcal infection.

questions.text: A patient presented with a fever for 11 days with neck rigidity. A lumbar puncture was done and it showed lymphocytes predominantly, Glucose 50 mg/dL, and protein 300 mg/dL. Gram-staining was negative. CXR of the patient shows upper lobe infiltrates with hilar lymph node enlargement. What is the diagnosis? (FMGE JAN 2023)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Tuberculous meningitis

 

The patient presents with symptoms indicative of meningitis, including fever, neck rigidity, and abnormal cerebrospinal fluid (CSF) findings. The CSF shows lymphocyte predominance, low glucose (50 mg/dL), and high protein (300 mg/dL), which are hallmarks of tuberculous meningitis.

 

Additionally, the chest X-ray (CXR) revealing upper lobe infiltrates with hilar lymph node enlargement further supports the diagnosis of tuberculosis, as these are common findings in pulmonary tuberculosis that can spread to the meninges.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Bacterial meningitis: Typically presents with neutrophil predominance in CSF rather than lymphocytes. The CSF glucose is also usually low, but the clinical and radiological findings here are not supportive of a bacterial etiology.

 

Option C. Fungal meningitis: Can present similarly with lymphocytic CSF and abnormal glucose/protein levels. However, the CXR findings of upper lobe infiltrates and hilar lymph node enlargement strongly suggest tuberculosis rather than a fungal infection.

 

Option D. Viral meningitis: Usually presents with normal glucose levels in the CSF, as viruses do not metabolize glucose. The patient’s low CSF glucose level makes this diagnosis unlikely.

 

Educational Objective:

 

For a patient with lymphocyte-predominant CSF, low glucose, high protein, and associated pulmonary findings such as upper lobe infiltrates with hilar lymph node enlargement, tuberculous meningitis should be highly suspected.

questions.text: Thrombosis of posterior inferior cerebellar artery causes? (NEET PG 2018)
questions.solution:
Ans. A. Lateral Medullary syndrome.

 

LATERAL MEDULLARY SYNDROME:

 

 

Other Options:

 

Option B: Weber is a medial midbrain syndrome caused by occlusion of PCA branches.

 

Option C: Medial medullary syndrome (aka Dejerine syndrome) supplied by vertebral/spinal artery.

 

Option D: Millard-Gubler is a lateral pontine syndrome involving peripheral LMN of 7th and 6th nerve (NOT NUCLEUS!) supplied by AICA.

 

Educational Objective:

 

 

Image showing arteries involved in brainstem syndromes lateral vs medial brainstem.

 

 

Reference - Harrison 21E/Chap 426/Neurology/stroke

questions.text: A young male presented with palpitations and hence ECG was taken. ECG demonstrated narrow complex tachycardia and his BP was 70/40 mm of Hg. What is the next step in the management of this patient?  (INICET MAY 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Synchronized DC Cardioversion

 

In the case of a patient presenting with palpitations, narrow complex tachycardia, and hypotension (BP 70/40 mm Hg), the patient is considered hemodynamically unstable. The appropriate management for an unstable patient with a pulse is synchronized DC cardioversion. This intervention is critical to restore normal rhythm promptly and prevent deterioration.

 

Synchronized cardioversion delivers a shock that is timed with the QRS complex, preventing the shock from falling on the T wave, which could induce ventricular fibrillation. This is the standard treatment for unstable supraventricular tachycardia.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. IV Adenosine (6mg): IV Adenosine is used for the treatment of stable narrow complex tachycardia. It is not appropriate for an unstable patient due to its transient effect and the need for rapid intervention in unstable conditions.

 

Option C. Carotid Sinus Massage: Carotid sinus massage is a vagal maneuver used to manage stable narrow complex tachycardia. It is not recommended for unstable patients because it may not be effective quickly enough to stabilize the patient.

 

Option D. IV Amiodarone: IV Amiodarone is typically used for stable wide complex tachycardia, especially monomorphic ventricular tachycardia. It is not the first-line treatment for unstable narrow complex tachycardia.

 

Educational Objective:

 

In hemodynamically unstable patients with narrow complex tachycardia, synchronized DC cardioversion is the immediate treatment of choice.

questions.text: An 18-year-old girl with the diagnosis of acute promyelocytic leukemia was treated medically. She developed fever and tachypnea and a chest X-ray showed pulmonary infiltrates. What drug should she be given next? (AIIMS MAY 2017)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Dexamethasone

 

APML is a leukemia with excellent prognosis managed with Arsenic trioxide and All-Trans retinoic acid. Differentiation syndrome is characterized by infiltrates, pleural effusion after treatment and improves with Dexamethasone. Used Intrathecally in children for AML.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Cytarabine is used in the treatment of acute myeloid leukemia.

 

Option C. Doxorubicin is a cardiotoxic drug used in Hodgkin, CA breast, thyroid.

 

Option D. Methotrexate is not recommended in APML treatment.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Dexamethasone is used to manage differentiation syndrome in patients with acute promyelocytic leukemia, characterized by symptoms like fever, tachypnea, and pulmonary infiltrates following treatment with specific leukemia drugs.

 

Reference -Harrison/Oncology/Acute leukemia/chap100-743

questions.text: The treatment of choice in acute sarcoidosis is? (NEET PG 2017)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Prednisolone.

 

Explanation:

 

Corticosteroids are the first-line treatment for sarcoidosis. In the management of sarcoidosis, immunosuppression with corticosteroids (specifically prednisolone) is the established primary therapy. This is particularly important in acute disease presentations where symptom control and prevention of progression are needed.

 

 Other Options:

 

Option B. Cyclosporin: While cyclosporine is an immunosuppressive agent, it is not the first-line treatment for acute sarcoidosis. It may be considered in select cases where corticosteroids are contraindicated or ineffective.

 

Option C. Infliximab: Infliximab is a TNF-alpha inhibitor that may be used in refractory cases of sarcoidosis, but it is not the first-line treatment for acute sarcoidosis.

 

Option D. IV Immunoglobulins: Intravenous immunoglobulins are not indicated as a primary treatment modality for acute sarcoidosis.

 

Educational Objective:

 

 Corticosteroids (prednisolone) remain the first-line treatment for acute sarcoidosis requiring therapy, with alternative immunosuppressive agents considered for steroid-resistant or refractory cases.

questions.text: Management of hyperkalemia includes all except : (AIIMS NOV 2017)
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Magnesium sulphate

 

Magnesium sulfate is not typically used for the treatment of hyperkalemia. It is more commonly used in the management of eclampsia in pregnant women and for its neuromuscular blocking effects in various other medical conditions.

 

Other Options:

 

The management of hyperkalemia typically involves interventions that stabilize the cardiac membrane, shift potassium into cells, and remove potassium from the body. Common treatments include:

 

Option A. Calcium gluconate: Which stabilizes the cardiac membrane and does not lower potassium levels but protects the heart from the effects of hyperkalemia.

 

Option B. Insulin drip: Often accompanied by glucose, which drives potassium back into cells, thereby lowering its serum concentration.

 

Option  C. Salbutamol nebulization: A beta-agonist that promotes the movement of potassium into cells.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Management of hyperkalemia

 

  • Calcium gluconate- reduces plasma K+ concentration by redistribution in cells rapidly
  • Insulin- lowers plasma K+ concentration by moving potassium intracellular, insulin dose used – 10units of IV regular insulin f/b 50ml of 50%dextrose
  • Salbutamol
  • Cation exchange resins, diuretics, dialysis.

questions.text: Which of the following is the drug of choice for hairy cell leukemia? (AIIMS MAY 2020)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Cladribine

 

It is a purine analogue used in the treatment of Hairy cell leukemia.

 

Cladribine-phosphates interfere with DNA synthesis and repair through incorporation into DNA and through inhibition of enzymes involved in DNA metabolism, including DNA polymerase and ribonucleotide reductase.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A & D are not used in Hairy cell leukemia.

 

Option C. Hairy cell leukemia patients have mutation in BRAF pathway and hence, Vemurafenib (BRAF inhibitor) is used as second line agent in refractory cases.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Cladribine remains the first-line treatment for hairy cell leukemia due to its high efficacy in inducing remissions.
